pros: Best work ever, good working environment
cons: I have nothing to say

pros: Able to do projects related to your job that you are interested in. Work culture is fantastic, great sense of ohana and family, genuinely.
cons: The salary range is low, which might be doable if Hawaii wasn't a high COL state

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Honolulu, HI
pros: -Working with prospective students and making dreams come true
cons: -no work-life balance. I was frequently denied vacation requests and had to work overtime on a regular basis with no overtime pay -leadership is out of touch and does not want to hear the opinions of their staff -the office location on Fort street is unsafe. Security will walk students at night but will not walk staff to their cars.

pros: Small university, good quality of students, good faculty who care about tour students
cons: We live in the state with the highest sot of living and yet we have no union, we are underpaid, and there is no effort on the part of the administration to to link salary increases with inflation, in fact we don't get any salary increases

job_title: Visiting & International Student Specialist in Honolulu District
pros: Great team, solid experience for those who want a foot in the door into international education
cons: Pay and benefits are low for skillset required, especially for Hawaii. You're often doing the work of two to three people.

job_title: Student Retention Specialist in Honolulu, HI
pros: Leadership, students, diversity, communication, involvement.
cons: I do not wish to share.

pros:
Students were great; most students were hardworking although this university has military students who always have some issues.
If you are very independent and self starter, you will like to work there.
cons:
The hourly rate is extremely lower and most professors are not supportive. Some instructors always come to class late, but nobody knows. Besides, some chair people love to get bribes so that those un professional instructors can keep teaching.
If you are in Hawaii, try to get a job at community colleges or UH.

pros:
Small university community
An organization that really lives out its values of Aloha, Pono and Kuleana
Friendly staff
cons:
Salaries on the low side
Benefits
Infrequent salary adjustments

pros: interesting research and ability to learn aquaculture research processes
cons: pay in science fields in general not great, but above min wage

pros: Decent benefits for full time staff
cons: Low work life balance heavy schedule

pros: co workers and benefits free parking
cons: too many mainland transplants. they gut all local staff replacing them with more mainland transplants. they usually stay only 3 to 5 years damaging the institutional knowledge by the local staff.

pros: Students are great and enthusiastic
cons: Some issues with upper management.

pros: Flexibility, learning environment, friendly supervisor
cons: Limited hours, expensive parking near work

job_title: Student Peer Mentor in Honolulu, HI
pros: Engage with freshmen students, work orientation, engagement between faculty and staff
cons: None that I can think of

review_title: Passion turned to TOXIC STRESS! Beware don’t work here!
pros: Students and it’s small campus
cons:
Hiring freeze for administrative support staff for years, severe budget cuts has lead to burning out dedicated staff & faculty.  This college has serious budgets issues. I will not be surprised when this college goes out of business.  
This place claims to have Hawaii values but treats their staff & faculty with little respect or compensation.  Beware & set boundaries with this employer. HPU will take advantage of your passion for education & will turn it to toxic stress by demanding more then you can do in a work week.  
Leadership says all the “right” words but their ACTIONS speaks louder then words.  When COVID first started, they picked money over the safety of their faculty, claiming it was to give the students more options. Yet, leadership was inflexible with staff & faculty to work from home. Insisting everyone return back to campus for the students but the students were not on campus.  Example of how inflexible they are: There is a staff member that has to bring his children to his office everyday because the leadership doesn’t believe in remote work!! In order to work from home you have to have a ADA condition. HR claims they will consider all ADA requests. I was asked for so many documents after my doctors wrote I was at a high risk for complications if contacting COVID but still insisted I should just go into my office.  Lack of compassion or flexibility and horrible pay.  If I could give this place negative stars I would

pros: Faculty and staff truly are committed to students
cons: Staff retention is a challenge

review_title: Great people and nice environment, but very bureaucratic
pros:
- The people are nice
- It's a collaborative environment
- Nice management who offer great flexibility
- Great work&study-life balance
- Opportunities for advancement if you do a good job
cons:
- Very bureaucratic
- Things take time
- Efficiency could be much better
- Communication between the different departments could improve significantly
- If you want advancement opportunities or professional growth, you have to specifically ask for it
- More responsibility doesn't always come with more pay, unfortunately

pros: Diverse population to work with.
cons: Not enough communication between all stakeholders.

pros:
Easy job
Ok people
Time to study
cons:
Pays minimum wage
No chance for advancement

review_title: Great students but admin doesn't support its teachers
job_title: Adjunct Professor of Writing in Honolulu, HI
pros: Student enrollment increased during the pandemic
cons:
Terrible pay
14+ adjuncts have to share one tiny office with only 1 desk 
Affordable parking is hard to come by

pros: Fun, get paid for taking notes that you've already been doing, got hired and processed fast
cons: n/a everything was pretty good

pros: good environment, chill, slow pace
cons: minimum hourly payment, part time

pros: Great working environment and friendly coworkers
cons: Minimum pays for student workers

pros: Mon. - Fri. work schedule, holidays off
cons: low pay, no career ladder

pros: good people have benefits nice environment.
cons: no bonus, low pay raise, slow growth.

review_title: Dr. Capaldo is the best lab supervisor
pros: Great research opportunities and professors
cons: Pre-health professions mentorship is lacking resources.

pros: Decent hours, flexible schedule, and nice location
cons: Low wages for living in Honolulu, HI

pros: Great place to work in Hawaii
cons: Nothing bad to say about it

pros: It is in Honolulu, Hawaii
cons: Pay, constant changes by administration disregarding academic input. Lack of support to professors.

pros: you get a flexible schedule with school
cons: Was only available to get up to 19 hours

pros: Great colleagues to work with
cons: Black-out periods on vacation use

pros: fun to help others with school
cons: can be slow some times

pros: Awesome experience and introduction into research
cons: Small space to work in, need more bench space

pros: Potential to take reduced price classes if they fit your schedule.
cons: Poor management, understaffed, high turnover rate, very disorganized. Expected to do way more than your role, without proper training or tools, and no additional compensation.

pros: Student diversity is the ultimate here, and just about everyone gets along.  There are some good departmental administrators too, although not so many are brave enough to buck the higher ups.
cons: Administration is wrong minded. Continuous new hires in business and administration, at $90,000+ salaries, when most faculty salaries are frozen for three years (or at least mine has been) at considerably less.  University talks about promoting scholarship and creative teaching, but fails to reward either one.  To make the salary issues more aggravating, the Chronicle of Higher Ed reports that female faculty are paid on average $20,000 less than male for same academic tier at HPU.  Most of us (except in business or higher admin) are disheartened. Another sad part is our marketing; our own communications and marketing people would do a better job of promoting the school than these expensive outside companies who haven't a clue about our values.  The school is in transition, though.  It is possible that things will get better if the new president embraces academic priorities.

pros: None none none none none
cons: No no no no no

pros: As a student worker at the school they help you by adjusting your work schedule around your class schedule. In my position I also had time to do my homework at work, as long as I didn't have appointments or meetings.
cons: Everything seem to take a long time, when I was re-hired after a break they had all my information in the system already, but the process still took several weeks before I was officially hired. The same went for any requests for schedule changes, you had to ask well in advance, or they wouldn't look at it and approve before the day of the change arrived.

pros:
You get paid.  And you do not have to work 100 hrs per week. 
If you are unethical and love giving easy grades for almost no work, this is THE place for you!
cons:
You get paid to babysit and give As to spoiled kids, most of whom are not prepared and/or immature and/or not really smart and/or entitled and/or lazy. Everyone is on the same page: students BOUGHT their easy As. The faculty are on it too..... That's how this work-life balance is achieved. 
There is no tenure. 
The school has super low academic standards, so it  has a low reputation and is having hard time being accredited. Students are totally not serious and often to not graduate. Faculty are lazy and do not do research and grants. The net result: there is always lack of students, and always financial problems and crisis.

pros: Student diversity.  Classroom environment is potentially terrific, for anyone who enjoys teaching.  Students are open-minded.  Have never enjoyed my students as much.
cons: Higher Administration is overly rewarded, while productive faculty are not.  There is no recognition of faculty accomplishment, no reward for publication, little support for it either.  Faculty are on the whole of low morale.  No one's job is secure.  Salary freeze for liberal arts.  New hires are paid more than people who have earned their oats, both in the classroom and larger academe.

pros: Valuable experience; depending on what job you've gotten. Sometimes there are jobs available for students such as sign-in assistants, which honestly don't do anything for you but give you an easy job. However, I was a marketing assistant that taught me quite a lot.
cons: Maybe it was just my supervisor but she didn't want to teach me most of the skills necessary to do the job because "I was not there enough". I'd say this was unfair because the only reason I wasn't there all the time was the simple fact that I am also a student, and her choice to not educate me in other aspects of the job left me doing mediocre work all through out. How can you expect someone to do the job if you don't tell them what they're supposed to do?

job_title: Technical Support Analyst in Honolulu, HI
pros: This is a part time position, so the hours are very flexible. They work with your schedule if you are an undergrad and the management of the IT department is awesome. There is also room for advancement once you graduate. They like to promote from within.
cons: Working for the IT department can be challenging at times. There are several professors who are downright rude to the staff and do not know how to use the equipment. Even though instructions are posted in the classrooms and multiple IT staff have shown them how to use it. The part time job is minimum wage and it can be a little frustrating when you get a difficult student or professor.

review_title: Fun, easy going, and flexible hours
job_title: Internal Mail Room Postage Allocator in Honolulu, HI
pros: Working at the campus as a student offers an abundant number advantages to working at off campus work sites.  For one, the school will more than likely be much more flexible with your hours and circumstances that arise because of school activities than other outside companies. My particular job in the mail room was a very fun and easy going environment.
cons: My time working for Hawaii Pacific University was very good so its hard to think of any cons honestly. I was always paid on time. If I wanted more hours or needed time off those accommodations were almost always met.

pros: Great students is.the only good thing about working here.
cons: Lack of leadership accountability. No recognition for better than average performance. Dehumanizing work atmosphere, no coherent goal-centered strategies. Leadership not attuned to Hawaii culture.

pros: The tutoring center I worked for within HPU was overall a really great experience. I worked while going to college (at HPU) and they were flexible about class schedule.
cons: There were times tutors would get overbooked, especially around finals, and it could be really stressful. You we're definitely expected to keep back to back appointments if you could, and sometimes would have to do group tutoring, which is even more stressful.

pros: Very fun and fulfilling being a tutor. Got paid to make a difference and gain some credits! Score!
cons: I could imagine having a snotty kid would be one but I was fortunate by having all good kids who were eager to learn and seemed to have fun with me. (They all got A's in their classes at the end of their semester. WOO!)

review_title: It is a nice place to work, with friendly people.
pros: Friendly people, nice students. It's a university, so you get non-teaching days off. I'm sure you can take sick days, but I never had to.
cons: The pay isn't amazing for adjunct faculty, but it's ok. Many of the students require ESL help (except for the mainland students).

review_title: The Aloha Spirit at Hawaii Pacific University
pros: You will work with really great and smart people.
cons: As is with other places that go through organizational changes, it can be very challenging to navigate the sea of change.  The university has gone through downsizing, two new presidents, and cuts to both faculty and staff, but I am confident that positive outcomes will arise from it all.

pros: They allow students to get involved and apply for some positions. This is a great opportunity for them the get the experience they need before they graduate.
cons: Hawaii Pacific University is a large university, but it is not as large as major universities, such as UH or other state schools. This can limit the power a position holds.

review_title: Diploma mill with no academic standards
pros: University generates some employment and tax dollars for state of Hawaii; immature incompetent students have a place to go to.  Employees do not have to work very much at all, as long as you give easy As, it's all good. It's like working in a middle school but for college pay.
cons: HPU is a scam. Employees are treated as retail consultants, selling diplomas. Students pay money and get As.  Students are lazy and very entitled, and rude to employees. There are NO academic standards. University was questioned by accreditation board and am not sure it is even accredited.

review_title: Once a contender, now a disaster
pros: There are none. It is a sham. Benefits have been cut, work load increased, and the policies are not even in line with the education sector. The new structure means there will probably be no long-term faculty building stable careers here.
cons: No job security. Climate of fear. No truthfulness on the part of management. Threats and intimidation on a daily basis. A truly toxic work environment. Some fantastic people working here but they are not valued at all. It used to be much better. This is just sad.

pros:
- President Gotanda is moving HPU in a great direction 
- A lot of paid holidays (18 per year), including a week off over Christmas and a great tuition benefit
- Great people 
- 4 weeks vacation (not the first few years tho)
cons:
- Health insurance cost (for family) 
- Parking 
- Compensation

pros:
Great opportunity to "cut your teeth" teaching at university level. 
Military campus programs allow you to work with fellow military members and trade ideas and knowledge.
Great response from permanent faculty and military campus advisors. Staff is very helpful.
cons: Personally, I'd prefer 1-2 hour classes instead of 4-hour classes; but it's not a bad schedule.

review_title: HPU, largest private university in Hawaii
pros: Location in Hawaii attracts amazing students from around the world. Central location. Generous retirement contributions.
cons: Staff and faculty are not valued. No one's job is ever secure. Superior pedagogy not valued or even encouraged by upper management. Programs are cut, people are terminated, important guidelines change with little advance notice,

review_title: A great place for student workers
pros: Worked with my school schedule while helping me build not only my graphic design portfolio, and help me building my skills as an editor; but gave me experience in event planning, public relations, social media for business, as well as a crash course in basic marketing.
cons: I really don't have any negative comments about my time working for the University and Alumni Relations departments at Hawai`i Pacific University

pros: LMS has many options available (HPU purchased a fully loaded version of Blackboard). Good library functionality. Good campus at Hawaii Loa.
cons: Have not raised adjunct pay in 10 years. Poor financial decisions by HPU leadership have resulted in increasing tuition, firing many employees, large classes, and poor organizational culture.

pros: They were willing to schedule work around a student's schedule.  It was a good learning environment, if you treated it like one.
cons: There were a lot of office politics.  Your position or connections directly relate to the amount of weight your opinions carried.

pros: HPU recently purchased the Aloha Tower Marketplace,  which will have student housing on the top floor, with retail and restaurants on the ground floor. University has not added student and staff amenities in other locations.
cons: Main campus is downtown, with limited parking. Suburban campus near Kailua and Kaneohe needs massive renovations.

pros: Excellent university to get your teaching start. I can only speak for the department I worked in, but the faculty and chair were helpful in helping me to acclimate and prepare for each course and the curriculum.
cons: This is a bit tricky, but would be nice if adjuncts received a few weeks notice if their projected class is in danger of being cut due to under-enrollment.

review_title: Benefits of working for a private university
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Honolulu, HI
pros: Company contributes 15% (based on salary amount to your retirement plan that you get to keep once you become vested (after 5 years).  Tuition benefits were amazing - two free classes a year and generous tuition discount off additional classes.
cons: Sometimes felt like a traveling salesperson with the long hours spent speaking to prospective at info sessions, education and career fairs, etc

pros: The retirement, sick and vacation benefit package is good. Everyday is different working here. I enjoy the different varieties that my job has to offer. The flexible hours are helpful when you have a 24 seven operation
cons: Medical and dental benefits are high for individuals and for family plans is even higher. If you can get cheaper that could help save money

pros: Diversity is the best in the world. And, of course, we're located in Hawaii, which doesn't hurt.
cons: Administration doesn't care about student success and retention. Doesn't understand what it means to do business in Hawaii. Inhumane philosophy for letting folks go. Unsustainable business practices and high turnover.

job_title: Recruiter/Assistant Director of Admissions in Honolulu, HI
pros: New management and a very genuine new school president! I enjoy working with new faces and fresh ideas everyday. The schools is heading in the right direction.
cons: Staffing and parking seem to be an issue with both new and old employees. Yet, this seem to be a downtown Honolulu issue too.

pros:
It's very chill here, as a student tutor, you'll be giving students tutoring sessions on 
the subjects of your choice.
Very chill, relaxed atmosphere, most of the supervisors are flexible and very nice, wiling to work with your schedule.
cons: Dress code can be a bit out of date and not very gender neutral for college.

job_title: Star of Honolulu in Wenham, MA
pros: It was a "work-study" position at HPU and it was convenient to work in between my classes
cons: The work was a little tedious; work-study employees at the financial aid office got the filing duty and receptionist activities as well.

pros: Great coworkers and staff.
cons: Upper Management wasn't great, and didn't really understand how IT works.

pros: It was a fast paced setting and challenging. A great environment working with a wonderful team and superiors.
cons: The cons was not coming from working with HPU, it was rather from starting anew in a city like Honolulu. Too expensive to get your foot on hold there.

pros: - you can build your career in a respectful environment
cons: - the pay is just enough to cope with the cost of life

pros: The people are dedicated, friendly, and hardworking.
cons: There are a lot of improvements to be done within the overall organization of the university. Things are disjointed but surely improving with the people that work there now.

review_title: A great school to work with and for.
pros: Great University to work with/for as they encourage employee development and are generally fun while they do the job of education!
cons: There are no cons that I can see!

pros: Wonderful faculty, diverse student population, beautiful location, entire program offered a tremendous amount of support to staff and students.
cons: Had to leave to return to mainland!

pros: Work loads are adequate and staff are friendly.  There is lots of communication between the support staff.
cons: Doesn't use the graduates from the University to fill positions.

pros: Great support staff!  Highly intelligent co-workers that tend to work well as a team.
cons: Workload is high in all areas. But worth it for the students!

pros: Ohana runs deep. I love working at HPU
cons: A little short staffed so you have a lot of responsibilities

pros: Good people to work with.
cons: Too much turnover at this time

pros: Pleasant atmosphere, change to make the University better.
cons: Declining enrollment for all colleges.

pros: You get different tasks to do and most of the staff is awesome.
cons: Pay is low and sometimes you can feel like your opinion doesn't matter.

pros: Client Services mag is amazing. Tier 2 is very cooperative with Tier 1 and is always helpful.
cons: Training for new employees needs some work.

pros: Excellent faculty, inquisitive, diverse student body
cons: Complete disorganization of senior administration and disjointed strategy

job_title: Assistant Computer Support Specialist in Honolulu, HI
pros: Except for a few, the people you work with are friendly and very tolerant.
cons: Maybe too laid back for some.

pros: great students; great environment and assistance provided
cons: class was eliminated and did not believe it should have been done

pros: Learned a lot about aquaculture, great co-workers
cons: Minimal chance for advancement, short staffed for the work that needed to get done

pros: I worked with great people who really cared about the students.
cons: Little trust in higher administration

job_title: Sports Information Director in Honolulu, HI
pros: Students are great and that makes the cultural experience fun. Colleagues some of the hardest working people I've ever worked with.
cons: Highly questionable decision making by senior leaders. School forced to sell a crown jewel of the island to pay for failing waterfront lease.

job_title: Director of Student Life in Honolulu, HI
pros: Super Fun! I'd work there again.
cons: None that I can think of.

review_title: Fair but could use better leadership in the management area.
pros:
Benefits on tuition
friendly work environment
cons:
-low pay
- promotions are based on manager's preference
- managers & directors need to be trained on how to manage people
